dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crewman EPPS (29), wearing a life vest and tool belt, jum down into the darkness. She stands in a great hollow cave oily, wet, resonant with the sound of creaking, rusty ste and WATER MOVING OVER ITS HULL on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps comes to a low point in the darkness, shining her li on a lake of salt water sloshing against the bulkhead. Sh kneels. As the water sloshes back she sees that it is lea in through the seams in the steel plate of the hull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps pulls herself onto the deck from below. She stands o rusting 5000 ton tank barge being pulled in the open ocea by a brawny marine tug at the end of a 150 foot tow cable It is a typical summer day in the southern Bering Sea, wh means a healthy chop and a stiff cold breeze out of the n west.  She closes the hatch behind her and makes her way  forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up ahead, the tug pulls steadily, grey-black clouds of di smoke rising from its massive turbine vents. Epps cinches and checks her body harness, focused and  professional. The product of a rocky childhood in the Pac Northwest and a few years of hard living, she's found her true calling now. And under some grime, several polypro s and a pair of orange men's Insulite pants she might even considered pretty. She clips her harness into the tow cable where it attache to a heavy pair of eye cleats at the bow. She climbs onto the cable, hanging out over the water as it breaks on the bow beneath her. She pulls herself forward on a roller be that fits over the width of the cable and starts off towa the tug at the other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DODGE and GREER look on from the stern, where the boat's  name "Arctic Warrior" is emblazoned on the transom. Dodge (37), scruffy chief engineer, wearing de rigueur greasy  coveralls and nicotine stained fingers, is an expatriate  Texan and former merchant marine. GREER (42), is the boat first mate, African American, originally from some swelte red-neck hellhole, now a tug pilot intentionally well to north. They watch as Epps pulls herself toward them, the cable  occasionally dipping a few feet with a spray of water as passing swell slackens it. Epps pulls herself to the ster where the cable winds into a tow anchor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a slow leak. She unclips and drops to the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's slow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe twenty gallons an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amidships starboard at the beam.   Just under the waterline. I don't  think it's a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear that, Dodge? Epps don't think  it's a problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll sleep good tonight knowing that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The view from the pilothouse commands 360 degrees as rada and GPS navigation displays glow. MURPHY, the ship's mast pilots the boat. He is 48, at sea all his adult life, and most of the rest, a fact written on his face and one that every crewman who's ever worked for him has been willing bet his life on. A walkie-talkie CRACKLES AWAKE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer to Murphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifting the radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go. Murphy turns back to see Greer, Epps, and Dodge looking u at him from the stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number nine on the starboard  side's half flooded. Epps says it's  a slow leak just under the waterline,  about twenty gallons an hour. They  must've pumped it before we left  Sitka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course they did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the buyer beware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say, Dodge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking the radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it started out at twenty an hour  the piece of shit'd be at the bottom  of the Gulf by now. Whether it'll  make St. Lawrence is anybody's guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HIGH AND WIDE as the Arctic Warrior pulls the barge again the swell of a grey ocean and a darkening sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shores of St. Lawrence Island open into a small port  town of mainly pre-fab buildings as the Arctic Warrior  approaches with the barge, now pathetically listing to on side as it moves into the harbor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smaller harbor tug helps the Arctic Warrior jockey the  listing barge to the dock as Epps and Dodge jump off to t her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer feathers the tug into position and shuts down the  turbines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy jumps down from the pilothouse to the deck as a fa Russian man, Vasili (60) and a MECHANIC in grease-covered orange coveralls approach from the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you say Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better late than never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing the listing  barge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a leak in the number nine  compartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no. You got leak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pump it out and re-seam the hull,  she'll be good as new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That cost me twenty grand at least.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifteen, at the most.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty. You knock off twenty and  then we see. After my guy looks at  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a prefab office with a view of the shipyard, Vasili cu a check as Murphy and Greer look on. He tears it out of t book, handing it across the desk to Murphy, who inspects

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're kidding, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want fair pay, make hamburger  for Mickey D. Otherwise, please to  sign. Vasili pushes a transfer register toward him. Murphy sign

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer and Murphy walk back toward the dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad for dragging a leaky tub  half way to Russia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'll sell the scrap for three times  what he paid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must be in the wrong business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got that right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Vasili)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than "making hamburger for  Mickey D."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A typical port town bar. Except this one is on an island the middle of the Bering Sea. Epps lines up a shot at the pool table as a couple of SEAMEN check out her ass and a  tattoo of Wiley Coyote poking out of her pants. Greer rea a paper near-by. Murphy enters, crossing to the bar where Dodge nurses a b and a cigarette. Murphy throws down an envelope with Dodg name on it. Dodge picks it up, thumbs through a thick sta of hundreds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much obliged, skipper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is a little more crowded now as Epps pushes her way through to the bar, a cigarette dangling from her mou She buys two beers and pays the BARTENDER from her envelo of cash. She takes the beers back to the far wall where a young off-duty COASTGUARDSMAN stands. He takes one, they  laugh.

dialogues.speaker: AT A TABLE
dialogues.text: Beers, cigarettes and pay envelopes on the table before t Dodge, Greer and Murphy look on at Epps across the room, is showing the coastguardsman a birthmark on her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like Epps' gonna get some  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With that coxswain dickhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You aren't jealous, are you Dodge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? Jealous? Epps?   Gimme a break. Greer and Murphy trade looks as Dodge raises his beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a laugh. A MINOR COMMOTION can be heard as they sit there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll show you, bitch! They look over to see the coastguardsman's GIRLFRIEND, la 20s, hefty in a red miniskirt and big hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to mess with me, I'll kick  your bitch ass, girl.

dialogues.speaker: WITH EPPS
dialogues.text: Epps coolly puts out her cigarette as a circle has gather around her and the girlfriend, anxious to see a girl figh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking  about. I just bought this guy a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This "guy" is my man, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, shut up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I don't want any trouble,  okay -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping Epps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-uh. No. We're gonna fix this right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What seems to be the trouble, ladies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whyn't you mind your own business,  chief. Murphy turns to see a shipyard RIVETER, a big man holding beer, still wearing his welding leathers. Murphy turns ba to Epps and the Girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I said, what seems to be the  trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you hear me, grandpa? Or you  got your hearing aid turned down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you. But I'm choosing to  ignore you. Epps, let's go. Epps starts forward but the Riveter stands in her way, ta Murphy by the collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These ladies was having themselves a  discussion and you're interrupting  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got about two seconds to get  your paws off me, Tarzan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or what? Or WHACK! Murphy can't help but wince as a pool cue break in two over the Riveter's head. Dodge, cigarette in his mouth, takes a look at the cue ha he still holds, shaking his head. The Riveter's hands fall from Murphy's collar and his leg buckle. Some of his BUDDIES hold him up as Greer reminds  some of the others he's holding a pool cue of his own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps? He looks to Epps like let's get the hell out of here. She grabs her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Epps holds there as the Coastguardsman steps up to his  girlfriend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darlene. It's over. He gives her the ring from his finger. Murphy rolls his e as the others look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't love you anymore. Darlene breaks into tears as they all look on, some pat h on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Epps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Candy. Let's get out of  here. The Coastguardsman takes her by the hand. Epps looks to M and the others as he leads her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy, Greer, and Dodge ready the tug to leave as Epps  approaches on the dock. She jumps down onto the deck, a s in her step and a song in her heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning everybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show your tatoos to that coxswain  last night, did you Epps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showed him a hell of a lot more than  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet you did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Candy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my pen name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy throttles up the turbines and backs the tug away f the dock as Greer studies the dawn sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red sky at night, sailor's delight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red sky in morning, sailor take  warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the tug turns into the harbor channel, the sun rising  under a cloud bank of brilliant red and orange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge and Epps play cards at the galley table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck it. He puts down his hand. Epps takes another drag from her  cigarette, collecting her winnings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not. She gathers the cards, shuffles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your first name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just occurred to me I don't know  your first name. All this time and I  don't know it. She deals the cards in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maureen? She looks on at him as he holds there, takes his cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's yours? Dodge takes a drag from his cigarette, thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. She wants to laugh, but only studies her cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that's funny

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She takes a hit from her cigarette as she plays her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE SONG "SOS" BY ABBA BLASTS as the tug plows westward  through a steady chop and a mild swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC COMES FROM HERE. Greer has the CD player cranke as he mans the helm in the glow of the pilothouse. He che the radar, holds there a beat. He turns the MUSIC DOWN an picks up a walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into walkie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer to Murphy. Greer studies the radar display as he waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a large vessel out about ten  miles to the north-west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy sits at his desk over the ship's log, holding his  radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I been watching it for close to an  hour and it hasn't moved. I can't  raise it on the radio either. Makes  me think it might be in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. I'll be right up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON RADAR DISPLAY as the sweep-refresh reveals a bri point of light in the middle of nowhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merchant vessel at position one seven  four one five west, five seven seven  five north. Murphy holds the radio mic as Greer looks on, Epps and Do standing back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is tugboat Arctic Warrior whiskey  alpha sierra bravo four zero niner  two. Over. Only the quiet hiss of white noise comes back from the ra speaker as the bright point flashes on the radar screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merchant vessel at one seven four  one five west, five seven seven five  north, this is tugboat Arctic Warrior  whiskey alpha sierra bravo four zero  niner two. Over. Again, only white noise comes back as the point flashes o the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too deep to anchor out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like it's adrift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could be a fishing boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too big. More like a freighter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell would a freighter be  doing up here? It's way out of the  lanes. There's not a port for 800  miles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smugglers maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smuggling what? Tundra grass? A beat as Murphy holds there. He raises the radio mic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Merchant vessel at position one seven  four one five west, five seven seven  five north, this is tugboat Arctic  Warrior. Do you copy? Over. Again, only the quiet hiss of static comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call the Coastguard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steer to one eight five. Let's check  her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Arctic Warrior cuts a foamy break in the ink black wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON RADAR DISPLAY as the phantom point flashes close Murphy looks on as Greer pilots, Dodge and Epps watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Back it off. Greer throttles back and the boat slows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The halogen flood lights flare to life, brilliantly  illuminating the water in front of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The four of them look intently into the darkness beyond t light. Murphy reaches for the spot control, sweeping a br beam of light with a joy stick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the tug moves along, servo motors sweep the searchligh over the bow of the boat and into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They peer into the night beyond the boat as it slowly mov when a shadow looms into view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa. Greer throttles down all the way and they drift, as the s looms bigger before them in the light from the boat. As they approach, the shadow appears to be a giant rustin bow, rising up from the water, disappearing in the darkne above them. Murphy sweeps the searchlight to reveal more what appears to be a large, darkened ship. As they come  around, the name "CHIMERA" can be seen above the anchor  alleys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Chimera." Murphy reaches for the mic, hits the LOUD HAILER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chimera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tug is dwarfed by the massive rusting hulk of the Chi rising above it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is civilian tugboat Arctic  Warrior. Is there anyone aboard? The quiet rumble of the tug's turbines is the only sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy raises the mic again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chimera, I am hove to at your port  bow. Is there anyone aboard? They wait, looking on at the silent, darkened ship under glare of their lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps, come with me. You guys sit  tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps and Murphy, in heavy parkas, climb a hydraulic deck  crane up to the Chimera as Dodge man's the controls again the movement of the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer holds the tug steady as Epps and Murphy can be seen making their way up under the floodlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy pulls himself up and jumps down onto the deck. Epp jumps down behind him. Murphy throws his light up on the  superstructure. All remnants of paint have been rusted ov lending a still darker ominousness to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy and Epps move cautiously along, shining their ligh as they go. Despite the omnipresent corrosion, everything seems to be in order. The decks are clear and there is no apparent damage. They come to a hatchway. Epps shines her light down the darkened passage. Murphy moves in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy and Epps move down the passageway. Even the walls here are rusted. They come to a flight of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer and Dodge wait. Greer reaches for his radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk to me, skipper. After a moment, Murphy comes back on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in a stairwell just under the  main superstructure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy and Epps climb the darkened stairway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is definitely an old boat, maybe  sixty years old. She hasn't been in  service for at least twenty years.  Probably a lot longer. They top the stairs and walk into a wider passageway whic takes them into an open area. Their lights shine around t revealing sinks and counters and racks of old kitchen  equipment, a few pots still hanging. They move through the galley and into another, narrower,  passageway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer and Dodge look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides a little rust, everything's  pretty well-preserved. Greer and Dodge look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How she got out here is one hell of  a good question. (a long beat, then)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Dodge and Greer hold there, waiting. Only silence from th other end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy. No answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy, goddamit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. Another beat in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy and Epps stand at the top of a stairway, looking o an immense ballroom. Murphy raises his radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a passenger ship. It's a damn  passenger ship. Though it is dark, there is enough light to see its ornat opulence, tables and chairs in place near a large dance f and orchestra well, and a magnificent crystal chandelier  hanging over it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps and Murphy climb down the deck crane as Greer and Do meet them at the bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jumping down)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nobody on that boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge, Epps, Greer and Murphy sit around the galley table

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably slipped her moorings, got  tangled up in a current.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out here? What, so a seven hundred  foot passenger liner drifted out of  Spokane harbor and nobody managed to  bump into her until now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody's probably looking for her  as we speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever the reason, she's adrift  and abandoned. We've got every right  to salvage her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean tow her back? That's a thirty  thousand ton ship you're talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've done it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, from one side of the harbor to  the other. But we got half the Bering  Sea and the whole Alaskan gulf to  drag her over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have any idea how much a ship  like that could be worth in salvage?  The fittings alone could go for a  few million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you get it back in one piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a risk I'm willing to take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All we got to do is hit some rough  weather and you can forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we cut her loose and wait it out.  A little weather couldn't be anything  she hasn't seen before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a bloody navigation hazard.   One boat can't control a ship that  size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The damn thing's been floating around  for God knows how long and it hasn't  hit anything yet. So we take it easy.  A little of the old push pull. A long beat as they hold there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. Forget this job's just a pay  check for a minute. You know I've  been good to you. But I'm prepared  to offer you something better now. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we do this right, it's worth a  lot of money. A lot of money. They hold there looking on at him, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Salvage fees on a vessel like this  could come in around four million  bucks. At least. Who knows, could be  more. Could be a lot more. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm proposing is... we split it  four ways. A beat. Dodge looks to Epps and Greer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think about it. A million bucks a  piece. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to spend the rest of your  days drag-assing tank barges on the  gulf coast, fine. Otherwise, let's  get to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tug is tied up alongside the Chimera, whose dark hull stretches off for seven hundred more feet in the light of day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy brings up the radio mic as Greer and the others lo on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: United States Coastguard, United  States Coastguard, United States  Coastguard. This is tugboat Arctic  Warrior whiskey alpha sierra bravo  four zero niner two. Over. After a moment, a distance-warped, coolly professional, f voice comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic  Warrior. This is United States  Coastguard Station North Island.  Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North Island, I wish to declare myself  salvor-in-posession under section  four two charlie of the International  Maritime Convention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. What  type of vessel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A passenger liner. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say again. Over. Murphy looks to the others, almost smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A passenger liner, north island.   Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the vessel name, registry,  and present position? Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passenger vessel "Chimera." I will  spell: charlie hotel india mary echo  romeo alpha. No registry information  is available at this time. I have  determined to the best of my ability  that the vessel has been abandoned  on the high seas at position one  seven four west, five seven north  at... (checking his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two zero one four hours zulu time.   Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. Please  advise your salvage authority pending  registry check. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger, North Island. Arctic Warrior  over and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge, Epps, Murphy and Greer are standing on the stern o the boat under the power winch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. We're gonna use a heavier than  usual twin cable rig this time,  consisting of a pair of number three  gauge braided wire tows. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll tie off through the anchor  alleys. And come down to the aft  port and starboard pins. Here.  Thus,  we need to get two of these... (indicating the cable)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up there. He indicates the bow of the Chimera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seeing as though a foot of one of  these fuckers weighs about a hundred  pounds, it ain't gonna be what you'd  call easy. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supposing one of those cables breaks  under tow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll all be doomed. Any other  questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy has backed the tug up to the bow of the Chimera. G operates the deck crane, one of Dodge's mammoth cables  dangling from it down to the winch on the stern.

dialogues.speaker: WITH EPPS
dialogues.text: Epps hangs on to the top of the crane as it comes to the  starboard anchor alley in the bow of the Chimera. Dodge p his face out from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring it on, dude. Dodge disappears from the hole and his hand comes back wi a smaller pilot cable, which Epps takes and threads throu the loop at the end of the tow cable. She places the end the pilot cable in a vice collar and uses a wrench to tig it down, with the effect of joining the two cables.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Dodge disappears, pulling up the slack from the pilot cab through the anchor alleys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finally)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hit it! Epps reaches over and unhinges the crane hook and the tow cable explosively drops, banging loudly against the Chime hull with a shower of black rust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge cranks a portable pulley winch on the deck, the pil cable slowly pulling the tow cable up through the anchor  alley. It is heavy and the winch shows the strain as Dodge crank it. He continues, when something gives in the winch mecha and the whole thing slides forward on the pilot cable,  entangling Dodge's leg and dragging him on his ass along deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tow cable creates a spray of rust and smoke as it spi out of the anchor alley before Epps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge slides toward the anchor alley like a piece of meat toward a sausage grinder, when the winch slams into it an stops dead, the cable continuing on with a loud shriek  dangerously close to his face, until...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the cable explosively whips out of the anchor alley in front of Epps and splashes in the water below. A beat as she holds there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge? You alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge lies tangled in the winch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two tow cables extend from the Chimera's anchor alleys do into the water and come up again from the water to the to anchor on the tug's stern. Dodge looks on as Greer and Epps stand by. He raises his  walkie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, skipper, real easy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy slowly throttles up, moving the boat forward. He t to see as the Chimera drops back behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tug moves slowly away from the Chimera as Epps, Greer and Dodge look on.

dialogues.speaker: TUG AND CHIMERA
dialogues.text: As the tug widens the distance, leaving the Chimera in pl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy holds the helm steady as the Chimera recedes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady as she goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge, Epps and Greer look on as the tow cables begin to  rise in their wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throttle back. The tug slows as the cables rise slowly from the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More. The tug slows still more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More. It slows still more, until the tug just creeps along, and the massive tow cables rise entirely out of the water,  straightening as the slack is pulled out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some fifty yards behind the tug, the tow cables come taug in the anchor alleys of the Chimera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy holds the throttle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right there, skipper. Right there. Murphy eases forward on the throttle and the turbines ris in pitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the tow cables stretch and the bow of the Chimera inch forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The turbines grow louder as Greer, Epps, and Dodge look o at the Chimera behind them, the massive tow cables bowing under their own weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy eases forward on the throttle, picking up speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The giant ship CREAKS AND MOANS as it starts forward, a s bow break forming on its hull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tug is kicking up a foaming wake as it pulls the Chim along behind it. Dodge lets out a hoot, exchanging high f with Epps and Greer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy smiles as he looks back at the Chimera following  behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A CHART. The south Bering Sea and the Gulf of Al A pencil traces a route.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I figure we go through at the Unimak  Pass here. Refuel at Sanak Island. Greer looks on from the helm as Murphy, Dodge and Epps st over the map table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a little extra fuel, weather  permitting, we should make Sitka in  five days without another stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds reasonable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hypothetically speaking, what if we  get this boat to Sitka and find out  somebody wants it back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shoulda thought of that when  they let her float away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what, ain't nobody just  gonna let us walk away with a ship  that size.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The law's on our side. If they want  to challenge it, let them try.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must've scuttled it. Nobody  just lets a ship float away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody just scuttles a passenger  liner either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever heard of insurance, big boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either way, we found it. It's ours  now -- . An EXPLOSIVE THUD shudders the boat. They look to each ot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (moving for the door)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge jumps down from the pilothouse as another LOUD THUM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting up to the  pilothouse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer shoves the throttle back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat goes dead in the water, thick black smoke billow from the turbine vents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as the bow slows in the water, the tow cables coming slac

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge pulls open the door. The place is thick with smoke he makes his way to the turbine gauges, Epps and Murphy  behind. Dodge opens the number one turbine cover, looks  inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother fucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Threw a turbine blade. Dodge looks over the smoking turbine, pulls back an alumi intake blade, hot to the touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer, Dodge, Epps, and Murphy confer on the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The number one turbine's pretty well  trashed. Number two runs, but it's  way underpowered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long to fix?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to say. I gotta get in there  and have a look. At least a couple  days. Depending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think the extra strain caused  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah. Everything was cool. It's just  one of those things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Arctic Warrior floats tied to the side of the Chimera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge has both turbines opened up as he works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights shine on what was once an elegant interior promena Murphy and Greer stand looking on at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some classy tub in it's day, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check this out.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE PURSERS DESK
dialogues.text: Epps looks through a file cabinet behind a heavy wood cou as Greer and Murphy approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's still here. Ticket  records, receipts, books of account. Greer picks one up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One first class passage. Elizabeth  James. Dubayy to Halifax. January  29th 1953. Murphy takes it, looking it over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chimera. Flag ship of the Dobbins  Kirk Line. Nova Scotia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy, Epps, and Greer top a staircase out onto a long,  darkened corridor. They move down. Some of the doors are  open, faint light from port holes showing small cabins wi beds, desks, a few chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy, Epps, and Greer come to a hatchway marked "BRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forward windows show the expanse of the ocean before  them and the rusting foredeck about 150 feet below. Light from the windows illuminates the bridge as Murphy, Greer Epps look around. Despite a little corrosion and a layer dirt, everything seems in its place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking through  scattered charts and  papers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd sure like to get my hands on the  general log. Epps steps up to the wall, where several framed photos ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That must be the old man right there. The uniformed man in the photo is a gaunt, stern-looking from another century, with dark, hollow eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like one hell of a stick up  his ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd let you off at the nearest port,  that's for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dimming purple horizon is giving way to night as the tu floats under the bow of the Chimera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge works up to his elbows in turbine 1 as Greer monito a pressure gauge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty pounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (geting up to have a  look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the pilothouse windows, the hull of the Chimera  disappears into the darkness beyond the tug's work lights Murphy sits at the chart table as Epps steps in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Thanks. She brings him his cup, seeing the documents he brought b from the Chimera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a seat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you find up there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some charts. A crew manifest. (looking them over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like her last voyage was January  1953. The question is where the hell's  she been since.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was sailing up north, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her destination was Halifax, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, suppose she got a little further  north than she should have.  Got  stuck in the ice. The passengers and  crew evacuated. She froze into the  ice pack, which moved further north,  where it froze in solid. They write  it off. Fifty years later, the whole  global warming thing happens. The  ice melts, she gets loose and floats  around til somebody runs into her. Murphy nods, considering it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As reasonable an explanation as any,  I guess. Epps takes a sip of her coffee as she thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever heard of the Mary Celeste?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a two-masted brig boat sailing  out of New York in 1872.  One day  she was sighted off the coast of  Portugal by a merchant vessel, the  Dei Gratia. As the crew of the Dei  Gratia got closer, they discovered  that no one was at the helm of the  Mary Celeste. On boarding, they found  her completely deserted. The captain,  his wife, their daughter, and the  entire crew, all gone. The last entry  in their log made no mention of any  trouble. The table was even set for  dinner. And in the nine days after  the last entry, she sailed 700 miles  without anyone aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows. There've been a lot of  theories, of course. But we'll never  really know for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think she's sailing without a  crew? Murphy looks out at the Chimera off the bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we'd be surprised where a  drifting ship might wind up with a  little wind and the right current.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're more practical than  superstitious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only way to be. Epps nods, takes another sip of coffee, looking on at the rusting hull of the Chimera stretching off in the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer operates the crane arm as Dodge directs him. The cr hoists out one of the massive turbine fans onto the deck. Dodge gives him the thumbs up as it comes down easily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turbine rotor's shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you said it was just a  blade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Metal's crystallized. Gotta replace  the whole deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much longer's that gonna take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like I always say --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I know, two ways to do anything --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The right way and the wrong way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We gotta get outa here, Dodge. A  storm blows up and we're history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, you don't want to  be running that fan like it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about running number two by  itself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a full 2500 horses down. We  couldn't drag that boat down hill on  ice with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta pull the blades and re-seat  everything in a new rotor -- .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three, four days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamit, Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want me to tell you,  that we can throw this sucker back  in and start pulling her like nothing  happened? Can't do it, skipper. A beat as Murphy stands there, knowing he's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the pilothouse)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic  Warrior. This is United States  Coastguard. Over. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy enters the pilothouse as the distance-warped VOICE comes back on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic  Warrior. This is United States  Coastguard Station North Island.  Over. Murphy raises the radio mic as Epps, Dodge, and Greer ste in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North Island, North Island, North  Island. This is tugboat Arctic  Warrior. Over. After a moment, the same professional, distance-warped vo comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctic Warrior, we have submitted  your section four two charlie salvage  notification. However, the  International Maritime Authority  record for a passenger vessel Chimera  indicates it was lost at sea in the  Gulf of Oman day two month two year  one nine five three.  Over. A beat as Murphy holds there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North Island, please repeat? Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctic Warrior, passenger vessel  Chimera was lost at sea day two month  two year one nine five three.  Over. Another beat as Murphy holds there, as the others look on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: North Island, have you got any  additional information? Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. The  vessel Chimera was registered to The  Dobbins Kirk Line, Halifax.  Nova  Scotia. Date of commission day nine  month seven year one nine three two.  Over. A long beat as the static of the open channel comes back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger, North Island. I am tied to  the passenger vessel Chimera. And  she is afloat. Repeat, she is afloat.  Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger, Arctic Warrior. I say again,  our records indicate the passenger  vessel Chimera was lost at sea.   Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger, North Island. Please advise  pending further information. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Affirmative, Arctic Warrior. This is  United States Coast Guard North Island  Station. Over and out. A beat as they hold there, thinking about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously it's some kind of screw  up. The shipping records aren't a  hundred percent accurate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, it gives me the creeps. We got  no business towing a ship that size  anyway. I say we fix the turbines  and hit the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you crazy? Do you realize we got  ourselves a ship? We own a ship,  Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, a ship that's supposed to have  been lost at sea fifty years ago.  You don't think that's just a little  freaky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this thing turns out to be a ship  everybody thought sank a long time  ago, we just hit the jackpot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well how the hell you get  something like that wrong? That's a  damn big boat. It's either sunk or  it ain't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all want to get outa here, Dodge.  Especially me. With that boat in  tow. You got three days.  Make the  most of it. A beat as Dodge looks back, then out at the Chimera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pencil point on a map follows across Saudi Arabia, comi to the Persian Gulf and tracing the coast of the Arab Emi to Dubayy. Murphy sits at his desk over the map. His pencil point fo the Persian Gulf from Dubayy, through the straight of Hor into the Gulf of Oman. Murphy marks an "X" there. A beat he looks on at it. He opens a large envelope he found aboard the Chimera. He empties it on the desk. He looks through it, docking rece from various ports of call, bills of lading, etc. He look over the passenger manifest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy wakes. He lies on his bunk, having fallen asleep l night in his clothes, still holding the envelope and some the papers inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge disassembles the turbine fans on deck as Greer read in the shade of the deck house. Dodge's hand slips and he skins his knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fucker!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, Dodge. It's only a  piece of metal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inspecting his skinned  knuckles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn mind of it's own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing Murphy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning, skipper. Murphy has stepped out into the sunlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're up late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I must've fallen back to sleep.  Where's Epps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Went aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She take a radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Murphy nods. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps steps from a passageway into a large public room. Ta and chairs are scattered haphazardly, light falling in fr windows along the wall where tattered curtains hang. She  walks on. A pair of empty glasses sit on a table, an empty sherry  decanter beside them. An ashtray sits beside that. Epps s reaching down. She pulls back a half-smoked cigarette,  lipstick smudging the end, yellowing and fragile from tim And, as she stands there, we see a FIGURE, IN MURKY  SILHOUETTE, MOVE PAST THE DOORWAY IN THE BACKGROUND. In a instant it is there and gone. She puts down the cigarette, having sensed a presence. Sh turns to the doorway across the room, but there is nothin to be seen now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A doll's white face, eyes haunting and coldly blue, stare into the middle distance. It lies on a love seat as Epps  steps up. She lifts it. Several other toys lie scattered  about as she studies it, when the sound of a TICKING CLOC CAN BE HEARD. A beat as Epps holds there. She turns, trying to locate t sound. From across the room, Epps stands, listening. As t TICKING CLOCK sounds from here. She turns, putting down t doll, holding a beat. She approaches, crossing the room,  coming finally to a stop before us and what we come to se is an ancient grandfather clock. All but it's minute hand has fallen off its corroded face but from inside it emits a weak though steady TICKING. Epps stands there as the clock ticks, looking on, when th TICKING CEASES. A beat as she holds there, as the clock f her, now silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps shines her light in the darkness as she comes to a d where daylight falls from a small port. She looks through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps stands in a white tiled room. Light falls from port  holes high in the wall. Running its length is a small swi pool, it's rusted fixtures and stained surface creating  bizarre patterns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps comes to a row of changing stalls. Old clothing hang there, unused for fifty years. A pair of woman's shoes li on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps moves along, passing through a doorway into

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps enters another room scattered with old exercise equi circa 1950, a wooden rowing machine, barbells and a medic ball. She steps up to the wall, where pictures hang. The Chimer can be seen in better days, sailing full speed on a calm  sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps jumps down to a lower deck. She shines her light up see that she is in an engine compartment, showing a massi diesel burner. She passes through into another compartmen where the giant pistons of the ship's power plant rise up the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps moves, passing still more diesel burners, towering o her in the cavernous space. She moves into a narrowing  passage, piping and machinery ducts winding their way int the depths of the ship. Finally the passage opens into yet another compartment,  apparently a cargo hold. Crates and boxes are stacked on  loading palettes. In the corner, a rotting canvas drape covers something. E comes to it. She lifts the canvas, which crumbles away to reveal a 1951 Ferrari sportster. For the exception of a c of dust and a small amount of corrosion, it is perfectly  preserved. Mail bags lie in piles along the wall, stacked between mo wooden crates and palettes, when something catches Epps'  eye. A heavy, metal door in the wall is twisted on it's hinges as though blown back from some terrific explosive force. Epps approaches, coming to the twisted door. She shines h light inside. A clutter of debris, shelving and wood, are visible in th shadows, when her light catches a glint of something. She swings her light back, revealing a yellowish bright objec between broken wood slats. Epps steps in. She kneels, shining the light closer. The  yellow glint is metal. Epps pulls back a slat, sliding aw some of the debris to reveal that it is cast from a kilog ingot of gold. She reaches out. She raises it, completely untouched by t years. She pulls back still more debris, revealing a stac of gold ingots, some having tumbled to the side. She slid away a large trunk that has fallen, pushing off more junk see that the stack is much larger, perhaps four feet high and five feet across. A beat as Epps stands there, looking on at $50,000,000 in gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The debris has been cleared away to reveal a clean 5'x 5' 4' stack of gold ingots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck we gonna do with it? Greer, Murphy, Epps, and Dodge all look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck you think we gonna do  with it? It's ours, baby. It's all  ours. Murphy has stepped forward, taking an ingot, inspecting i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much you figure that's worth,  skipper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still looking it  over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hard to say. Maybe forty, fifty  million.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ho, baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lot of money for somebody  to just let float away. Murphy looks up at her from the gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. A beat as they all hold there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hell of a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, you think there's something  funny about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ship with fifty million dollars in  gold aboard, adrift? And nobody seems  to care enough to come looking for  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they thought it was lost at sea,  they probably just wrote it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for fifty million. An ocean liner  maybe. But fifty million in gold,  they come looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they didn't want it back.   Maybe the whole fat deal was insured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. But there's always somebody  whose interest's at stake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I gotta say is it looks like  that somebody's us right now. Greer cackles as he high fives Dodge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it looks like somebody got here  before us too. The steel hatch is twisted, as from a great hand ripping back from the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inspecting it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't happen yesterday, I'll tell  you that. Torn parts rusted bad as  the rest of the boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it happened before they scuttled  her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, before she sank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cargo like this could make a crew  think twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That it could. A beat, as they all look on at the gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After dinner, Murphy, Greer, Dodge and Epps sit around th galley table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why didn't they take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably didn't have time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or somebody stopped them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either way, they must've had a pretty  good reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a damn good reason to jump  ship and leave fifty million dollars  aboard. A beat as they consider it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what're we gonna do. That's the  big question, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A salvage claim to a vessel's cargo's  as valid as a claim to the vessel  itself. It's ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we're rich. We're damn, filthy  stinking rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks like it. A beat as they let this sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what? We gonna unload the gold  and get a move on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We leave it where it is. Stick to  the plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta be kidding? What the hell  we need that tub for, we got fifty  million bucks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we get a little more for the boat.  Besides, the gold'll be safer where  it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but we still gotta haul that  big piece of shit all the way back  to Sitka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worth the effort. Believe me.   Besides we're gonna need her to prove  the salvage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not call for help?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For now the best thing we can do is  to keep quiet about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last thing we want is extra partners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or uninvited guests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge, you gotta get on those repairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah. I'm on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sooner we get under way, the  sooner we are to spending what's  ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge, wearing a welding mask and gloves, braises an alum fitting over one of the open turbines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps finishes stacking the gold ingots in a cleared space beyond the twisted hatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred twenty. Two twenty one. (as Epps stacks the  last one)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two twenty two. Greer makes a note.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two hundred twenty two kilograms of  solid gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I call a payday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell yeah. They slap hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy moves down the darkened passage, coming to a door  marked "CAPTAIN." The door is ajar. He pushes it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy stands in the doorway of a spacious cabin panelled dark wood. A large desk occupies a corner of the room by windows. Though dirty and worn with time, everything is  ordered and in its place. Murphy comes to the desk. He sits down in the chair behin it. The surface is clear and uncluttered. He pulls out th drawer to reveal pens, writing paper, a ruler, compass an protractor amidst other sundry items.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Murphy steps in. The room is undisturbed, light falling i on the taught green bedspread through dirty, tattered  curtains.  A robe hangs on the back of a chair. A pair of slippers lie beneath it.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Murphy stands in the bathroom. The tile has yellowed with time, but everything is exactly as it was left. Even the  shaving kit is neatly arrayed on the sink as Murphy looks at it. He looks up, seeing himself in the mirror, when an EXPLOSION SOUNDS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy comes to the railing, looking out over the bow of ship to see black smoke rising from where the Arctic Warr is tied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer and Epps run to the side to see billowing smoke ris from the Arctic Warrior as Murphy climbs down the crane t the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy jumps down to the deck. Flames belch from an open  hatch as Murphy grabs a fire extinguisher from a deck loc coming to the engine room door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy enters to find the engine room engulfed in flames black smoke. He finds Dodge spraying at it with an  extinguisher of his own. The flames belch up from an oil fire in the turbine well, the heat searing paint on the metal covers. Murphy sprays cloud of halon and the fire dims, but only for a moment. Dodge grabs another extinguisher, his leg burned, face an hands singed. An EXPLOSION ROCKS THE BOAT and molten flames hurl throug the air, catching Murphy's pant leg. He's so engrossed in fighting the flames, he doesn't realize he's on fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the roar)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy! Murphy looks down to see his pant leg is on fire, as Dodg turns a cloud of halon on him, putting it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Propane tanks're gonna go! Murphy crosses in the smoke, coming as close as he dares the most intense part of the flames. He turns the extingu into them, holding it there. The flames dim, as Dodge joins him on the other side, tur his extinguisher on it too. The fire seems to dim yet aga as clouds of halon rise up. Fire belches from a duct, crawling across the ceiling. Do fires his extinguisher at it, pushing it back across to t wall again. Murphy extinguishes the last of the flames in the turbine well as Dodge brings a snaking tendril of fire down to th deck, and finally out. They stand there in the sudden silence, the air heavy wit smoke. A fine layer of halon powder lies over everything, but the fire is out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge smokes a cigarette, now starting to feel his burned leg, which is oozing as Murphy and Greer look on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One minute I'm minding my own  business, the next thing I know the  whole place is burning up. (taking a drag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An oxygen tank must've blown on the  welder. Started an oil fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like it took out the backup  genny too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific. Epps arrives with a first aid kit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's that leg? Epps cuts back the burned pant leg to see the burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen better -- Ow! Epps cleans the burn with hydrogen peroxide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This's gonna hurt a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for the warning -- Ow! Damn! Epps keeps cleaning as Dodge bears it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We could call for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And get a bunch of fools sniffin'  around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What other choices have we got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you one thing, we're not gonna  be towing no ship now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gas lantern sits on the map table illuminating Murphy a he holds the radio mic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to radio)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: United States Coastguard, this is  tugboat Arctic Warrior whiskey alpha  sierra bravo four zero niner two.  Radio check. Over. A moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arctic Warrior, Arctic Warrior, Arctic  Warrior. This is United States  Coastguard Station North Island.  Your radio check is affirmative.  Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roger that, North Island. Arctic  Warrior whiskey alpha sierra bravo  four zero niner two. Over and out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge pours out a few cans of cold chili into a bowl and  takes it to the table where Epps, Greer, and Murphy sit u the stark light of a gas lantern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty million four ways. That's twelve  million and change a piece.  What  you gonna do with your share, skipper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not much at all, I guess. Retire.   Live out my golden years and all  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm buyin' me a nice outrigger.   Spend my time hauling rich Seattle  business men through the Puget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you Epps?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess I'll just keep working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moving to Sweden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so great about Sweden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a beautiful country. Very clean.  Very civilized. And cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, yeah. I like it cold. Colder  the better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but not as cold as those Swedish  girls you only gonna dream about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see who's dreamin', m'man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dreamin's all any of you're gonna be  doing if we don't get this boat  running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is that? The SHRIEKING CONTINUES, ECHOING EERILY AS IF FROM THE SE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge, Epps, Murphy and Greer emerge on deck. The DISTANT SHRIEKING IS LOUDER HERE, BUT SEEMS TO BE  EMANATING FROM DEEP IN THE SHIP as they stand facing it o the bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's coming from inside. They hold there listening as the SHRIEKING CONTINUES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like the hull.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Warm water current maybe, making the  metal expand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That shit is seriously bizarre. The DISTANT SHRIEKING ECHO continues as they hold there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The engine room is black with soot, the turbines covered halon powder. Dodge stands there looking at it. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer goes through shelves of supplies, finding a stack o sterno cans and warming candles. He throws them into a wo crate of other supplies he's gathered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps slowly pushes open the door. She holds a sack with a few items she's managed to scavenge. Light falls from  curtained windows onto the room. A divan sits against the wall. A table stands in the middle of the room, a moth-ea velvet table cloth sitting under a brass lamp on top. Two twin beds stand on either side. They are covered in dust are moth-eaten, unmade, as if the occupants had just gott up, fifty years ago. In one corner is an armoire. Epps steps up to it, pulling back the door to reveal a rack of woman's clothing hangin there undisturbed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of slippers lie on the floor beside a chair, over  which is draped a woman's robe. Epps lifts it, the materi crumbling in her hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A drawer comes back to reveal a number of personal affect a man's billfold, cuff links, tarnished silver cigarette  holder and case, coins, black horn-rimmed glasses, pocket watch and fob, and a room key. Epps pulls back the billfold. She opens it. Inside she fi a Canadian passport a picture of a dark-haired man with a mustache and black horn-rimmed glasses, circa 1950. In th folds she finds three hundred Canadian dollars. An insert holds pictures, of a suburban home, children, and a woman presumably his wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps steps from the room. She turns to close the door, bu stops, holding there, strongly sensing something. THE CAMERA SLOWLY COMES AROUND TO HER OTHER SIDE, reveali the long passageway behind her, each bulkhead hatchway  creating the impression of a tunnel of mirrors that frame one another and, standing at the very end of this tunnel the foggy light from a porthole, a MAN in dark clothing. Epps slowly turns her head to see what she already senses the man standing at the end of the passageway facing her. beat as they hold there. The man only stares back at her, then turns to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! Epps moves off as the man walks around the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait a minute! Hey! MOVING WITH Epps as she breaks into a run, going down the passageway. She comes to the corner, rounding it out onto another passageway. The man is nowhere to be seen. Epps moves quickly down the passageway, coming to the nex corner, rounding it out to see only another long passagew She turns back, running right into Murphy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take it easy, you'll live longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guy. He just came this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's somebody else on this boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? What the hell're you talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw him. Just a minute ago. Some  guy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm sure. I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure it wasn't me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't you. It was somebody else.  There's somebody else aboard. A beat as Murphy looks back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greer, Dodge, Murphy, and Epps stand around by lantern li

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light in those passages ain't so  good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, I saw somebody. I  don't know who it was. But I saw  somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd he look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe six feet. Lanky. I didn't get  a good look. He was far away. But I  saw him. I saw him as sure as you're  standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's his boat, then? Where's his  crew? He ain't gonna be out here by  himself, that's for damn sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's so big somebody could come  alongside her on the other side and  we'd never know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that is his boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme a break. A beat as they sit in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If somebody's aboard her already,  she ain't ours. She's theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. That boat hasn't made steam  for fifty years. We found her. She's  ours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in the eyes of the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, we find this guy and make a deal  with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't exactly have the best  bargaining position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say fuck the motherfucker. We're a  professional salvage crew going about  our business. What's some yahoo doing  way out here by himself anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what do you propose? That we  knock this guy off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Why the fuck not? A beat as Murphy, Greer and Epps exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty million dollars. Fifty million.  We gonna let this guy just take it  from us? One guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we kill him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm saying we gotta do whatever we  gotta do to preserve our interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's just take it easy here, alright?  Nobody's gonna kill anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supposing he wants to get bad with  us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One guy isn't gonna be so stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe he isn't alone. They consider this a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say we off-load some of that gold  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you hold on just a minute here,  please? Look, there's no reason to  panic now. Epps saw somebody. Fine.  It's a big boat.  Chances're real  good he doesn't even know about the  gold. If we stay cool, nobody'll be  the wiser. (a beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gold stays where it is til we're  ready to go. Like I said, it'll be a  hell of a lot safer there than here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if that fucker finds it before  we're ready to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll stand a watch. Four on, eight  off. Low man first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess that'd be me. Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dodge, get on that turbine. I don't  care if you don't sleep for a week.   The sooner you're done, the sooner  we can get out of here. How's the  food situation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty low all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to take it easy then. I  don't think we'll find much aboard  the ship, but it's probably worth  looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say we run into this guy again. A beat as they consider this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If he's reasonable, maybe we can  make some kind of deal. If not.   We'll have to re-consider our options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, reconsider fucking his shit  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps is dressed in her cold weather gear as she opens a  locker, revealing a flare gun and a shotgun. Epps pulls b the shotgun and a box of shells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murphy and Dodge look on as Epps loads the last of severa shotgun shells into the pump action short barrel 12-gauge She expertly shuttles a round into the chamber with one h Dodge takes a hit from his cigarette as Greer crosses fro the deck house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty handy with that scatter gun,  Epps. You raised on a farm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (setting the safety)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen a lota movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cowboy shit up there, understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No cowboy shit. Right. Greer extends a thermos to Epps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pocketing it in her  coat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a pal. She checks the squelch on her radio, pockets it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got your light?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smokes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Her bravado does little to hide her apprehension as she s the shotgun on her back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you boys later. (to Greer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be late, I need my beauty rest. She looks up, climbs onto the crane and up toward the dar ship above them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flashlight beam cuts through the darkness as Epps  approaches. If this place is creepy in the daylight, it i terrifying now. She comes to a ladder and climbs down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps shines her light as she passes through, coming to th cargo hold. She crosses in the darkness, her light catchi the tarnished glint of the gold. She comes up to it, stop there, looking on at it, a perfectly symmetrical fortune. She looks around for a place to sit. She drags a palette the bulkhead, settling in to face the rest of the compart She puts her shotgun down beside her and takes out her th to pour herself a cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps has dozed off when a CLATTERING ECHOES DISTANTLY  somewhere in the ship. Epps wakes. It is silent, as she h there, not sure she heard anything, when a DISTANT BOOMIN SOUNDS. She reaches out for the shotgun, intently listeni As Epps holds there, another deep BOOMING sounds distantl somewhere. Epps turns, her blood running cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps moves along in the darkness when the DISTANT BOOMING CAN BE HEARD BRIEFLY AGAIN. She stops, holding there, in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Epps jumps down into the shaft alley where the ship's mas propeller shaft hangs suspended above her. Epps moves alo Finally she comes out into...
